Situation1: This is the last weekend before the partner relocates abroad for months.
Situation2: A main production unit has paused for thirty minutes because of recurring sensor errors.
Story: I sat across from Alex at our favorite café, the clock ticking louder in my mind than the chatter around us. This was our last weekend together before he left for Singapore, and I’d promised him my undivided attention. He reached for my hand, his eyes searching mine for reassurance, but my phone buzzed again—another urgent message from the plant. The main production unit was down, and the team couldn’t get past the sensor errors. I was the only one who knew the system inside out. My manager’s texts grew more desperate: “We need you now. Every minute counts.” Alex squeezed my hand, his thumb tracing circles, silently pleading for me to stay. My heart twisted as I tried to focus on his words, but my mind raced with possible causes for the shutdown. I felt torn in two, the weight of responsibility pressing from both sides. I wanted to be the girlfriend Alex needed, to make these last hours count, but I also knew the factory was counting on me. The pressure built inside me, and I stared at my phone, paralyzed, caught between love and duty.
